awd_titl_txt: Testing models of ancient forager social and territorial organization with a strontium isoscape
awd_abstract_narration:
For most of human history, people have developed different technological and social strategies to reduce the risk of food insecurity in different environments. These strategies are expected to differ systematically depending on the abundance and predictability of food resources in time and space. This project will use chemical and archaeological evidence to investigate how human hunter-gatherers used flexible social and territorial organization strategies to minimize risk in different environmental conditions. The research will shed light on how humans have coped with variable environmental conditions in the past, and how they may do so in the future. This project will create opportunities for American undergraduate students, especially those from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields, and postdoctoral researchers, to learn chemistry laboratory methods.  It will also build research infrastructure through the training of collaborators from the developing world in environmental sampling protocols. Results will be disseminated by peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, and science outreach. Primary data will be permanently publicly available through the Digital Archaeological Record website.

Chemical "fingerprinting" of foods in different landscapes and human teeth formed at different developmental ages permits reconstruction of human residential histories and mobility patterns. This project will use multiple analytical chemistry techniques, including multi-elemental and strontium isotope ratio-based provenience analysis, to investigate diet and residential histories of pre-agricultural Later Stone Age (LSA) humans between approximately 12 and 6 thousand years ago.  The primary objective is to determine how LSA peoples adapted to different resource distributions through contrasting social and territorial organization strategies: territorial defense to preserve exclusive access to abundant and predictable resources, versus extended social networks for sharing information to reduce risk of resource failure in unpredictable environments.  Chemical methods for determining the geographic source of human and animal remains will be refined through the analysis of samples of modern soil, airborne dust, plants, mollusk shells, and mammal teeth, and archaeological human teeth. East-Central Africa is an ideal place to examine the relationships among environmental conditions, resource distributions, and socio-territorial organization strategies. Environmental records from East-Central Africa suggest more stability and thus less dramatic contrasts in resource structure during the last 15 thousand years compared to eastern and southern Africa. At present, this region has a long stressful dry season. This dry season may have been longer and more severe during past arid phases and shorter and less severe during wetter phases. Therefore, this an important time and place to investigate contrasting social and territorial strategies for resource exploitation and risk reduction. The results of this research may provide guidance for developing policies and predictive models of human strategic social and territorial organizational responses to changing environments. The methodological refinements developed in this project will be readily transferrable to the earth, environmental, and social sciences, as well as forensic investigations, food origins authentication and biological conservation.

por.por_cntn:
The ultimate goal of this project is to test hypotheses of social and territorial organization and intergroup social network patterns of hunter-gatherers in changing environments and climates by provenience analyses of archaeological mollusk shell, ostrich eggshell (OES), and shell ornaments by analysis of their strontium isotope ratios (87Sr/86Sr). Strontium isotope analysis is considered a powerful tool for reconstructing geographic and geologic locations of faunal and human remains and artifacts. Provenience analysis is based on the fact that you are what you eat: the strontium isotope composition of plants reflects that of the bedrock and soils they grow on, and this isotopic fingerprint is preserved in the animals that feed on the plants within their home ranges. Provenience can be reconstructed where systematic spatial differences in bioavailable 87Sr/86Sr (isoscape variation) occur at the scale of human and animal seasonal movements, home ranges and inter-group exchange and mating networks.

The proximate goal of this project was to construct a foodweb strontium isoscape in the Kasitu River and Mt. Hora area of Mzimba District, northern Malawi, primarily using modern plants and mollusk shells. This region was selected because models of human social and territorial organization are being tested with materials from archaeological sites in the Mzimba survey area that contain Later Stone Age (LSA) hunter-gatherer occupations dating to the last glacial era and the post-ice age warm period. Human and other animal teeth, and shell ornaments, are particularly useful for Sr isotope analysis. People may move from their natal territories during their lifetimes, particularly after marriage, herbivore prey may move seasonally between uplands and valleys, and ornaments may have been exchanged through social exchange networks among members of different communities over short to long distances. Strontium isotope analysis can identify the chemical fingerprint or tracer to reconstruct residential life histories of individuals, and object biographies and itineraries of artifacts that may have been acquired through social exchange networks.

Isoscape fieldwork focused on a ~55 km diameter area centered on Mt. Hora. A total of 185 relatively evenly spaced plant samples were collected across the 55 km diameter survey area during three field seasons from 2017 to 2019. Several undergraduate and graduate students participated in the sample collection and laboratory analysis phases of research. Fieldwork was conducted by post-doctoral scholar, co-PI Andrew Zipkin in 2017. Dr. Zipkin performed and supervised lab work and methods development at the U. Illinois Urbana-Champaign (UIUC) Environmental Isotope Paleobiogeochemistry Laboratory (EIPL), using mass spectrometry instruments in the UIUC Geology Department, and Illinois State Geological Survey (ISGS) through 2018. Dr. Zipkin and the student research assistants acquired valuable professional experience and training in scientific research.

The results of Sr isotope analysis within this survey area reveal two types of spatial variation patterns. First, stream and river valley floodplain grasslands have generally lower 87Sr/86Sr in compared to surrounding hills. Second, the southeast half of the survey area had lower 87Sr/86Sr ratios than in the northern half of the isoscape survey area. At the scale of human mobility and territory size this isoscape could cover parts of up to four average hunter-gatherer group home ranges. This large scale pattern of isoscape spatial variation may be useful for reconstructing provenience of people and their artifacts, as well as herbivore migration and seasonal habitat selection patterns. It indicates good potential to fulfil the important MALAPP anthropological archaeology objective of reconstructing human residential life histories, interaction, exchange and social networks and object biographies.

The ultimate goals of this research have broader impacts and relevance for society beyond training students and post-doctoral scholars in scientific research. These anthropological objectives are relevant for advancing our understanding of the origin and development of patterns of modern human social organization and the foundations of adaptive variation in social and territorial organization. Combined with the archaeological evidence, this isoscape research can contribute to our understanding of the basic human capacities for adaptive resilience and flexibility in responses to environmental change. We can draw on our understanding of the past to guide our responses to accelerating global environmental change.
